1.SubTopic: Apply place-value strategies to solve problems.
Content: Carla has a list of three numbers.
• Carla’s numbers are in order from least to greatest.
• The first number in her list has the least tens.
• Every number in her list has fewer tens than ones.
Which list of numbers could be Carla’s list?

Key.Rationale: Does not realize that 153 has fewer ones than tens.
Ignores that the second number has more tens than ones.
Does not realize that the numbers are not listed from least to greatest.

2.SubTopic: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by two-digit multiples of 10 (from 10 through 90).
Content: Mrs. Jackson has 47 boxes of crayons.
There are 8 crayons in each box.
To estimate the total number of crayons, she uses the steps shown below.
• round 47 to the nearest ten
• multiply the new number by 8
What is Mrs. Jackson’s estimate of the total number of crayons?

Key.Rationale: Adds the 8 to 50 and then puts a 0 on the end.

3.SubTopic: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by two-digit multiples of 10 (from 10 through 90).
Content: George bought 9 cases of bottled water.
Each case had 18 bottles of water in it.
To estimate the number of bottles of water he bought, George rounded 18 to the nearest ten and then multiplied that number by 9.
What is George’s estimate of the number of bottles of water he bought?

Key.Rationale: Rounds correctly but then appends the 9 to the 20.
Rounds correctly but then adds the 20 and 9 and puts a 0 on the end.

4.SubTopic: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by two-digit multiples of 10 (from 10 through 90).
Content: Kelly is planting groups of seeds.
She places 4 seeds into each group.
She plants 22 groups of carrot seeds and 38 groups of lettuce seeds.
How many total seeds does Kelly plant?

Key.Rationale: Adds 60 and 4 and then appends a 0.

5.SubTopic: Order a set of whole numbers from least to greatest or greatest to least (up through 9,999, and limit sets to no more than four numbers).
Content: Three students were comparing how many times they each jumped on a trampoline.
Jorge jumped 345 times.
Keisha jumped 356 times.
LeVar jumped more times than Jorge and fewer times than Keisha.
When each student’s total was rounded to the nearest hundred, Jorge’s total and LeVar’s total were the same.
Which value could be the number of times LeVar jumped on the trampoline?

Key.Rationale: Picks a number that rounds correctly but is not greater than 345.
Thinks 362 < 356 because of the 2 in the ones place.

6.SubTopic: Order a set of whole numbers from least to greatest or greatest to least (up through 9,999, and limit sets to no more than four numbers).
Content: The table below shows the number of loaves of bread baked at a bakery on three days.
problems/PA15G3M/media/6a.jpg
Which list shows the days in order of total number of loaves of bread baked from least to greatest?

7.SubTopic: Represent fractions on a number line (limit denominators to 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8; limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator; and no simplification necessary).
Content: In Sierra’s third-grade class, 3/8 of the students are boys.
Which number line has a point on the fraction of the students that are boys?

Key.Rationale: Knows 3/8 is less than 1/2 but not able to compare to 1/4.
Moves 3 tick marks from the wrong end of the number line.
Thinks 3/8 is greater than 3/4 because 8 is greater than 4.

8.SubTopic: Compare two fractions with the same denominator (limit denominators to 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8), using the symbols >, =, or <, and/or justify the conclusions.
Content: Bill and Cindy ate some pieces from the same pie.
Bill ate 3/8 of the pie.
Cindy ate 1/8 of the pie.
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: Bill ate more pie than Cindy.

B.Choice: Cindy ate more pie than Bill.

Key.Rationale: Confuses fraction comparison rules: thinks fractions with the smaller numerator are greater.

C.Choice: Bill and Cindy ate the whole pie.

Key.Rationale: Thinks each person ate half the pie.

D.Choice: Bill and Cindy ate the same amount of pie.

Key.Rationale: Thinks the fractions are equal since the denominators are the same.

9.SubTopic: Demonstrate that when a whole or set is partitioned into y equal parts, the fraction 1/y represents 1 part of the whole and/or the fraction x/y represents x equal parts of the whole (limit denominators to 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8; limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator; and no simplification necessary).
Content: Fatima drew the figure shown below and shaded part of it.
problems/PA15G3M/media/9a.jpg
Which fraction is equal to the amount Fatima shaded?

Key.Rationale: Ratio equivalent to 1 shaded and 3 unshaded parts.

10.SubTopic: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions (limit the denominators to 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8 and limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator).
Content: There are 8 players on a basketball team.
There are 4 girls on the team.
What fraction of the players on the team are girls?

Key.Rationale: Incorrect simplification of fraction, subtracts 3 from numerator and denominator.
Incorrect simplification of fraction, divides numerator by 4 and denominator by 2.

11.SubTopic: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions (limit the denominators to 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8 and limit numerators to whole numbers less than the denominator).
Content: Lou bought 6 doughnuts.
There were 2 doughnuts with sprinkles.
Which fraction represents the doughnuts Lou bought that had sprinkles?

Key.Rationale: Starts with 2/6 and subtracts 1 from numerator and denominator.
Uses the number of unsprinkled doughnuts for the denominator.
Starts with 2/6 and adds 4 to the numerator and denominator.

12.SubTopic: Interpret and/or describe whole-number quotients of whole numbers (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10).
Content: A pet store has a total of 24 fish tanks.
A worker at the pet store puts the fish tanks in rows.
There are 6 fish tanks in each row.
The expression shown below can be used to find the number of rows.
Which sentence about the rows of fish tanks is true?

A.Choice: There are 4 rows of fish tanks.

B.Choice: There are 6 rows of fish tanks.

Key.Rationale: Uses the divisor as the number of rows.

C.Choice: There are 8 rows of fish tanks.

D.Choice: There are 24 rows of fish tanks.

Key.Rationale: Thinks the dividend represents the number of rows, not the total number of tanks.

13.SubTopic: Use multiplication (up to and including 10 × 10) and/or division (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10) to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and/or measurement quantities.
Content: Brent gave 8 colored pencils to each of his 4 friends.
Which number sentence can be used to find the total number of colored pencils (□) Brent gave to his friends?

14.SubTopic: Use multiplication (up to and including 10 × 10) and/or division (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10) to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and/or measurement quantities.
Content: Kayla has 12 seeds.
She plants an equal number of seeds in each of 4 pots.
How many seeds did Kayla plant in each pot?

15.SubTopic: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication (up to and including 10 × 10) or division (limit dividends through 50 and limit divisors and quotients through 10) equation relating three whole numbers.
Content: Jill puts 24 brownies onto □ plates.
She put 4 brownies onto each plate.
The number sentence below can be used to find how many plates Jill uses.
How many plates (□) does Jill use for brownies?

16.SubTopic: Apply the associative property of multiplication (not identification or definition of the property).
Content: There are 3 gorillas living in a zoo.
Each gorilla eats 40 pounds of food each day.
The expression 3 × 7 × 40 represents the total amount of food, in pounds, the 3 gorillas eat in one week.
Which expression also represents the total amount of food, in pounds, the 3 gorillas eat in one week?

17.SubTopic: Apply the associative property of multiplication (not identification or definition of the property).
Content: There are 4 tables in Cleo’s classroom.
She puts 2 packages of crayons on each table.
Each package has 8 crayons.
Cleo finds the total number of crayons on the tables by multiplying 4 × 2 × 8.
Which expression shows another way Cleo could find the total number of crayons on the tables?

Key.Rationale: Uses addition symbol instead of multiplication symbol.
Applies commutative property, but with addition symbol.
Applies commutative property, but with addition symbol.

18.SubTopic: Relate division to a missing-number multiplication equation.
Content: Joey has 27 toy cars.
He puts an equal number of cars on each of the 3 shelves in his room.
He uses division to find the numbers of cars on each shelf.
Which number sentence shows a way Joey could find the number of cars on each shelf?

Key.Rationale: Adds the numbers given in the stem.
Uses multiplication, but incorrect placement of numbers.

19.SubTopic: Interpret and/or model division as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor.
Content: There are 6 ponies for children to ride at the fair.
In one hour, the ponies gave a total of 42 rides.
Each pony gave the same number of rides.
The equation below shows how to find the number of rides (□) each pony gave.
Which equation shows another way to determine how many rides (□) each pony gave?

20.SubTopic: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.
Content: Eva buys 3 bags of balloons.
There are 4 red balloons and 5 blue balloons in each bag.
Which expression shows how many red and blue balloons Eva buys?

Key.Rationale: Uses addition and multiplication but in incorrect locations.

21.SubTopic: Use operations, patterns, and estimation strategies to solve problems (may include word problems).
Content: A bathtub is filled with 50 gallons of water.
Each gallon of water weighs between 8 and 9 pounds.
Which weight, in pounds, is closest to the weight of the water in the bathtub?

22.SubTopic: Represent two-step word problems using equations with a symbol standing for the unknown quantity. Limit to problems with whole  numbers and having whole-number answers.
Content: Ed picked □ baskets of berries.
Jasmine picked 2 more baskets of berries than Ed picked.
Ed and Jasmine picked a total of 8 baskets of berries.
Which equation can be used to find the number of baskets (□) Ed picked?

Key.Rationale: Uses 2 for total number of baskets picked by Jasmine instead of 2 more than “square”.
Same number of baskets picked by each.
Wrong operation, multiplies for 2 more than “square”.

23.SubTopic: Represent two-step word problems using equations with a symbol standing for the unknown quantity. Limit to problems with whole  numbers and having whole-number answers.
Content: Carlos volunteers □ days at the library each month.
In March, he volunteered 3 extra days at the library.
In January, February, and March, Carlos volunteered a total of 39 days at the library.
Which pair of equations shows the number of days (□) Carlos volunteers each month?

Key.Rationale: Finds the total number of regular days.

24.SubTopic: Represent two-step word problems using equations with a symbol standing for the unknown quantity. Limit to problems with whole  numbers and having whole-number answers.
Content: Last year, José subscribed to 4 different magazines.
He received 6 issues of each magazine.
He also bought 7 issues of other magazines at a bookstore.
Which pair of equations shows the total number of magazine issues (□) José got last year?

Key.Rationale: Adds all the numbers in the problem together.
Multiplies the wrong two numbers together.

25.SubTopic: Identify the missing symbol (+, –, ×, ÷, <, >, and =) that makes a number sentence true.
Content: A number sentence is shown below.
Which symbol goes into the □ to make the number sentence true?

Key.Rationale: Thinks since one symbol is ×, the other should be ÷.

Content: Marquis and Shawn built a tree house.
The shape of the floor of the tree house is a quadrilateral.
The shape of the floor is not a rectangle or a rhombus.
Which quadrilateral could be the shape of the floor of the tree house?
A map is drawn in the shape of a square.
The map is then divided into parts.
Each part has an area equal to 1/4 the area of the entire map.
Each part is a rectangle but is not a square.
Which figure could show how the map is divided?

Key.Rationale: Selects a figure with 1/4 the area but divided into squares.
Selects a figure with areas equal to 1/9, not 1/4, of the total area.
Selects a figure in which the areas are neither rectangles nor squares.

Content: Carol draws a rhombus.
It is not a square.
She divides it into three equal-size parts.
Which figure could be Carol’s rhombus?

29.SubTopic: Recognize rhombi, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals and/or draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Content: Paul divides a shape into two parts by drawing one line as shown below.
problems/PA15G3M/media/29a.jpg
Which term describes the two parts and the original shape?

Key.Rationale: Counts 2 shapes with 4 sides each = 8 sides.
Shape on right is a rhombus.
Considers only the right shape and does not consider the angle measure.

30.SubTopic: Recognize rhombi, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals and/or draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Content: Four shapes are shown below.
problems/PA15G3M/media/30a.jpg
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: The four shapes are all trapezoids.

Key.Rationale: Thinks trapezoids have at least 1 pair of parallel sides, not exactly 1 pair of parallel sides.

B.Choice: The four shapes are all rectangles.

Key.Rationale: Confuses third shape for a rectangle.

C.Choice: The four shapes are all quadrilaterals.

D.Choice: The four shapes are all parallelograms.

Key.Rationale: Thinks parallelograms have at least 1 pair of parallel sides, not 2 pairs of parallel sides.

31.SubTopic: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Content: Lee has quilt patches.
Which quilt patch has 1/4 of its area shaded?

Key.Rationale: 1/5, ratio of 1 section shaded to 4 sections unshaded.
1 of 4 areas, but area is only 1/6 of the patch.
1 of 4 areas, but area is only 1/6 of the patch.

32.SubTopic: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, money, liquid volumes, masses, and lengths of objects.
Content: Dana has three coins in her pocket.
No two coins have the same value.
What is the least amount of money Dana could have in her pocket?

Key.Rationale: Counts two nickels and a penny.
Uses a quarter, dime, and nickel (no coins the same, but not least possible amount).

33.SubTopic: Determine or calculate time and elapsed time.
Content: Three friends ran in a race.
The race started at 12:55.
The pictograph below shows the time it took each friend to finish the race.
problems/PA15G3M/media/33a.jpg
At what time did Zack finish the race?

Key.Rationale: Uses Val’s row and forgets to multiply by 2.

34.SubTopic: Tell, show, and/or write time (analog) to the nearest minute.
Content: Kelly went to bed 30 minutes after the time shown on the clock.
problems/PA15G3M/media/34a.jpg
At what time did Kelly go to bed?

35.SubTopic: Calculate elapsed time to the minute in a given situation (total elapsed time limited to 60 minutes or less).
Content: Marco arrived at the beach between 10:30 a.m. and 10:35 a.m.
He left the beach between 11:10 a.m. and 11:15 a.m.
Which is a possible amount of time Marco was at the beach?

Key.Rationale: Only looks at the hours (11 − 10 = 1 hour = 60 minutes).

36.SubTopic: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or liquid volumes that are given in the same units.
Content: Ethan is knitting a blanket.
He will use 20 balls of yarn.
There are 8 ounces of yarn in each ball.
How many ounces of yarn will Ethan use to knit the blanket?

Key.Rationale: Uses addition instead of multiplication and incorrectly adds the 8 to the 2 in the tens place.
Confuses multiplication rules and incorrectly appends the 8 to the end of the 20.

37.SubTopic: Make change for an amount up to $5.00 with no more than $2.00 change given (penny, nickel, dime, quarter, and dollar).
Content: Dante bought a package of carrots that cost $3.76.
He used $4.00 to pay for the carrots.
Which group of coins shows the correct amount of change Dante should receive after paying for the carrots?

Key.Rationale: Displays change paid, not change received.
Wrong coin amounts, uses nickels instead of dimes.
Subtraction error, subtracts.25 and then adds.01 instead of subtracting.01.

38.SubTopic: Round amounts of money to the nearest dollar.
Content: Megan buys a book.
Rounded to the nearest dollar, her book costs $8.
Which amount could be the exact cost of the book?

Key.Rationale: Rounds the 4 to 5 and then the 7 to 8 (double rounding).
Rounds down by subtracting 1 from the ones place.

39.SubTopic: Complete a scaled pictograph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories (scales limited to 1, 2, 5, and 10).
Content: There are 77 third graders at Tyler’s school.
Which pictograph shows this number of third graders rounded to the nearest 10?

Key.Rationale: Rounds down to 70 and uses a scale of 20.

40.SubTopic: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Display the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked in appropriate units—whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Content: Kim measured the lengths of nails she found.
She made the line plot shown below.
problems/PA15G3M/media/40a.jpg
After making the line plot, she found two additional nails.
problems/PA15G3M/media/40b.jpg
Use your ruler to measure the lengths of the two nails.
Which line plot now shows the lengths of all the nails Kim found?

Key.Rationale: Measures the second nail as 2 inches, accidentally starting at 1/4.
Measures the nails as 1 2/4 inches and 2 inches, off by 1/4 inch in both cases.
Includes only the second nail in the line plot.

41.SubTopic: Translate information from one type of display to another. Limit to pictographs, tally charts, bar graphs, and tables.
Content: The table below shows how much time Sam practiced each week.
problems/PA15G3M/media/41a.jpg
Which bar graph shows how much time Sam practiced each week?

Key.Rationale: Bars in ascending order by height.

42.SubTopic: Find the areas of plane figures.
Content: The drawing below shows Simone’s bedroom floor.
problems/PA15G3M/media/42a.jpg
What is the area, in square meters, of Simone’s bedroom floor?

Key.Rationale: Counts the squares and adds 1 for the rectangle.
Counts the squares and adds the dimensions of the rectangle.
Adds area of rectangle and counts the squares.

43.SubTopic: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in., square ft, and non-standard square units).
Content: Sara had a map in the shape of a square.
Part of the map was torn off.
The part of the map that Sara still has is shown.
problems/PA15G3M/media/43a.jpg
Each small square on the map represents 1 square unit.
How many square units did Sara’s map have before it was torn?

Key.Rationale: Just determines the height of the map.
Counts the full squares on the torn map.
Counts the full squares and every partial square on the torn map.

44.SubTopic: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
Content: Natalie made a rug in the shape of the rectangle shown below.
problems/PA15G3M/media/44a.jpg
Which rug has the same area as the one Natalie made?

Key.Rationale: Value of perimeter (20) same as value of given area.

45.SubTopic: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas, and exhibiting rectangles with the same area and different perimeters. Use the same units throughout the problem.
Content: The size and shape of home plate on a baseball field are shown below.
problems/PA15G3M/media/45a.jpg
What is the perimeter, in inches, of home plate?

Key.Rationale: Forgets to include the 17 inches at the top.
Multiplies 8 × 17 as if finding the area of the rectangular portion.
